hits.title: Dark Chocoalte Potato Chip, Brie and Red Wine Dry Salami

ingredients.ingredient: Fantino and Mondello Sliced Red Wine Dry Salami
Coarsely Chopped Wonderful Salt and Pepper Pistachios

steps: Select 24 full, large Compliments Original Kettle Cooked Chips from the bag and chill them in the refrigerator.  Reserve the rest of the kettle cooked chips for snacking.
Coarsely chop the pistachios and Compliments Dried Cranberries.  Mix them in a small dish and set aside for garnishing

Gently melt the Compliments Dark Chocolate Chips with the vegetable oil in a microwave, using short 20 second bursts, stirring in between, until smooth.  Dip two-thirds of each chilled Compliments Original Kettle Cooked Chips in the melted chocolate.  Transfer to a parchment paper lined tray and refrigerate for 10 mins to set.

Meanwhile, fold each slice of the red wine dry salami in quarters, pinching the folded edges to secure its triangular shape, set aside. Slice the brie cheese into 24 pieces at 1” long by ¼” thick and set aside.
Arrange the chocolate dipped Compliments Original Kettle Cooked Chips on a platter.  Top each with a folded red wine dry salami and a piece of the Compliments Double Cream Brie Cheese.
Garnish each with a sprinkling of the chopped pistachio and Compliments Dried Cranberries over top of the brie cheese.  Serve immediately.
tips: The Dark Chocolate Covered Compliments Original Kettle Cooked Chips can be made the day before and stored in layers separated with parchment paper, in an airtight container at room temperature away from sunlight and moisture.
hits.featuredImageAltText: Dark chocolate potato chip, brie and red wine dry salami on two serving plates on a blue countertop.
hits.metaTitle: Dark Chocolate Potato Chip, Brie and Red Wine Dry Salami
hits.metaDescription: The combination of dark chocolate chips, red wine dry salami, and double cream brie cheese is sure to be a hit with all your party guests this holiday season.

hits.title: Blue Cheese and Genoa Hot Salami Dates

ingredients.ingredient: Castello Danish Extra Creamy Blue Cheese
Panache Tangy Red Pepper Topper and Spread
Finely Crumbled Compliments Salt and Vinegar Kettle Cooked Chips

steps: Pre-heat oven to 400˚F (205˚C) and line a baking tray with parchment paper, set aside.  Using a paring knife, carefully cut a slit on one side of each date, opening them like a book.

Divide the blue cheese into 24 by 5g pieces, approx. 1 tsp each.  Fill each date with a piece of the extra creamy blue cheese.  Close the dates around the blue cheese and wrap each date with a folded slice of the Panache Genoa Hot Salami.  Pressing to flatten ever so slightly and seal the ends of the genoa salami closed.
Transfer the dates to prepared baking tray, seam side down, and roast them in the pre-heated oven for 7-8 mins, and the genoa hot salami is slightly golden/crisped.

Gently heat the Panache Tangy Red Pepper Topper/Spread in a microwave at 20 seconds bursts, stirring in between until smooth and slightly liquid.  Liberally brush each of the dates with the Panache Tangy Red Pepper Topper/Spread to glaze.
Transfer the warm, glazed dates to a platter and top each with the crumbled Panache Salt and Vinegar Kettle Cooked Chips and finely sliced chives for garnish.  Serve while warm.
hits.featuredImageAltText: An overhead shot of blue cheese and genoa hot salami dates on a big round plate and smaller serving plates on the side.
hits.metaTitle: Blue Cheese and Genoa Hot Salami Dates
hits.metaDescription: Try this delicious appetizer for your holiday spread. Fresh Medjool dates stuffed with creamy blue cheese, wrapped in salami, and topped with fresh chives.

hits.title: Easy Cheesy Shrimp and Crab Mini Casseroles

ingredients.ingredient: Compliments Naturally Simple Frozen Black Tiger Shrimp 21/25 Thawed, Peeled, Deveined, Tail Off
Coarsely Crushed Compliments Sweet Chili and Sour Cream Kettle Cooked Chips

steps: Pre-heat your oven to 375°F (190°C), and lightly oil 8 x 8oz (1 cup, 250 ml) individual ramekins.  Place the ramekins on a rimmed baking tray and set aside.
Bring a salted pot of water to a boil over high heat.  Cook the elbow macaroni until al dente, approx. 6 mins.  Drain well and let cool while you prepare remaining ingredients.

In a mixing bowl whisk together the Compliments Alfredo Sauce, garlic powder, and old bay seasoning, until blended.  Add the cooked macaroni, Compliments Naturally Simple 21/25 Black Tiger Shrimp, crab meat, grated smoked gouda cheese, grated medium white cheddar cheese, chopped parsley, and 1 Cup (250 ml) of the coarsely crushed Compliments Sweet Chili and Sour Cream Kettle Cooked Chips, mixing well.

Divide the shrimp casserole mixture evenly between the prepared ramekins, making sure each dish gets the same quantity of shrimp, 4+ each.  Sprinkle the top of each shrimp casserole lightly with the remaining coarsely crushed kettle chips and bake uncovered until shrimp are cooked through, cheese has melted, and casserole is bubbling, approx. 20-25 mins.
Remove the mini shrimp casseroles from the oven and let cool slightly.  Garnish with the finely sliced chives and serve.

hits.title: Roasted Mediterranean Seabass with Citrus and Herbs

ingredients.ingredient: (4) Whole Frozen European Sea Bass Raw, Thawed

steps: Pre-heat your oven to 400°F (205°C) and line a rimmed roasting pan with foil.

In a bowl, whisk together the olive oil, 3 tbsp (45 ml) of the chopped parsley, thyme, rosemary, garlic, oregano, paprika, salt, pepper and the juice from 1 lemon (1/4 cup, 60 ml, 59g) until well blended.  Set aside.  Halve the remaining lemon length wise and thinly slice (12-15) each half, set aside.

Cut three slits into the flesh on both sides of each fish.  Transfer the branzino to the prepared roasting pan.  Pour the oil and herb mixture over the fish, rubbing the oil all over, into the cuts and belly cavity of each fish.  Nestle a slice of lemon into each of the cuts on the fish.  Place any remaining lemon slices inside the belly cavities of the branzino.
Roast the branzino on the center rack of the pre-heated oven for 15 mins.  Then turn the broiler to medium high and broil the branzino for 3 mins.
Remove the roasted citrus and herb branzino from the oven and let cool slightly.  Transfer the whole fish to a platter, garnish with the pan juices and remaining fresh chopped parsley.  Serve.
hits.featuredImageAltText: Two roasted Mediterranean seabass with  citrus and herbs on a green oval plate with two spoons and water glasses on a blue background.
hits.metaTitle: Roasted Mediterranean Seabass with Citrus and Herbs
hits.metaDescription: Roast a whole Mediterranean seabass this holiday season. With citrus and herbaceous notes, this will make a great centrepiece for your Christmas dinner.

hits.title: Apple and Cranberry Coleslaw

ingredients.ingredient: Panache Dressing Red Wine and Shallot

steps: Heat a small pan on your stove over medium heat.  Add the almonds, tossing occasionally, toasting until light golden brown, approx. 3-4 mins.  Set aside to cool.

Heat canola oil in a deep sided pot over medium high heat to a temperature of 375°F (190°C).  Fry the rice vermicelli noodles in batches until puffed and crisp, approx. 5 secs.  Gently turn noodles over, using a slotted spoon, and fry 2 secs longer.  Transfer fried noodles to paper towel-lined plate to drain.  Set aside.

Spoon ¼ cup (60 ml) of the Panache Red Wine and Shallot Dressing on the bottom of a large bowl and set two-thirds of the fried vermicelli on top of the dressing.  Begin arranging the julienned vegetables in a pyramid-like shape around the fried rice vermicelli noodles; julienne granny smith, finely sliced red cabbage, julienne carrot, julienne daikon, julienne red onion and julienne red pepper.

Drizzle the arranged vegetables with remaining ¼ cup (60 ml) of the dressing.  Top the coleslaw with the finely sliced green onions, chopped Compliments Dried Cranberries, fried onions, and toasted sliced almonds, building the coleslaw as tall as possible.  Lightly crush the remaining fried rice vermicelli noodles and sprinkle over the coleslaw.
Bring the coleslaw to your table and gently mix in front of your guests, blending the coleslaw and dressing throughout.  Serve.
tips: If you don’t have a thermometer to measure the oil temperature for frying.  Test with a small piece of rice vermicelli noodle.  When the oil has reached 375°F (190°C) the noodles will puff up in 2-3 seconds when dropped in the hot oil.
hits.featuredImageAltText: Apple Cranberry Coleslaw on a teal plate, topped with fried noodles and almonds, served with small blue bowls on the side, against a blue background.
hits.metaTitle: Apple Cranberry Coleslaw
hits.metaDescription: Try a Jewish deli classic with apple cranberry coleslaw. Made with fresh cabbage, and Granny Smith apples, the dried cranberries offer a touch of sweetness.

Bring the coleslaw to your table and gently mix in front of your guests, blending the coleslaw and dressing throughout.  Serve.

hits.title: Inspired Cioppino Seafood Stew

ingredients.ingredient: Diced Fennel, fronds reserved for garnish
Compliments Diced Tomatoes with Italian Seasoning
Compliments Naturally Simple Frozen Black Tiger Shrimp 26/30 Thawed, Deveined and Peeled, Tail On
Fresh Shucked Choice Oysters, on the half shell

steps: Heat a large pot over medium high heat, add the olive oil, onion, fennel, and green pepper.  Season lightly and cook stirring occasionally until softened without caramelizing, approx. 8 mins.

Add the tomato paste, garlic, red pepper flakes and bay leaves, stirring often, cook for 2 mins.  Stir in the diced tomatoes, roasted red pepper, and vegetable broth.  Bring to a simmer, season lightly with salt and pepper, let simmer for 10 mins.

Meanwhile, shuck the fresh oysters leaving them on the half shell, keep refrigerated.  Separate the snow crab clusters into individual legs, lightly crack using the back of a knife carefully or hands, without fully breaking the legs, and keep refrigerated.

Once ready, add the mussels and snow crab legs.  Cover,  and bring to a simmer, cooking for 4 mins.  Gently stir in the diced white fish fillet, and shrimp.  Simmer until mussels have opened, the fish and shrimp are just cooked through, approx. 4 mins longer.  Season lightly and stir in the parsley, taste and adjust seasoning to taste if needed.
Divide the Cioppino Seafood Stew evenly between soup bowls.  Garnish each with a fresh shucked oyster on the half shell, a pinch of the chopped fennel fronds and parsley.  Serve immediately.
tips: Serve with thick slices of grilled sour dough bread for dipping in the flavourful cioppino broth.

To pre crack the snow crab legs, carefully use the back of a knife, meat tenderizer or your thumbs to gently crack-don’t fully break the surface of the crab shell.  Try to simply split the shell without crushing the meat inside.  Focus on the lightly coloured, more pliable part of the legs shell for an easier cleaner crack.  A light pre-crack helps the flavours from the cioppino permeate the shell and makes it much easier to remove the shells once the legs are cooked.

hits.title: Deconstructed Lobster Ravioli

ingredients.ingredient: Whole Fresh Cooked Lobsters, Approx 1 ½ lbs (680g) Cooked, Shelled Lobster Meat Coarsely Chopped
thinly sliced fresh asparagus coins and tips
Compliments Fresh Lasagna Sheets, Halved Lengthwise

steps: Bring a large, salted pot of water to a boil over high heat.  Meanwhile, heat the olive oil in a large saucepan over medium heat, add the onion and sauté stirring often until softened without caramelizing, approx. 4-5 mins.  Stir in the minced garlic, sauté until fragrant, 30 secs.  Add the white wine and cook until the wine has reduced by half, approx. 1 min.

Stir in the marinara sauce and cream, bring to a gentle simmer.  Add the asparagus coins/tips, cooking gently for 1 min.  Add the shelled lobster meat and cook until the lobster is heated through, and the asparagus are tender, approx. 3 mins longer.  Season with salt and pepper, then add the halved cherry tomatoes.  Stir and turn off the heat, keeping the sauce warm on the stove.

Cook the halved pasta sheets in the boiling salted water until just tender, approx. 9 mins.  Gently drain the pasta, taking care not to damage the cooked pasta sheets, separating them so they don’t stick together.

When plating, make sure everyone gets an even amount of lobster, asparagus, and halved cherry tomatoes.  To serve; lay the bottom 1/3rd of a cooked pasta sheet in the center of 8 pasta bowls.  Gently spoon 1/4 cup (60 ml) of the lobster sauce on top, then sprinkle with a pinch of chopped parsley, a basil leaf and a pinch of the grated parmesan cheese.  Repeat the process two more times, garnishing each finished dish with the remaining chopped parsley, basil leaves and grated parmesan. Serve.

hits.title: Seared Scallops with Apple & Brown Butter Pan Sauce

ingredients.ingredient: Compliments Naturally Simple Wild Atlantic Canada Sea Scallops (20-40 count), thawed
(1 mL) each salt and coarse black pepper
Granny Smith Apple, peeled, ½ in. (1 cm) dice
(30 mL) finely sliced Compliments Fresh Chives

steps: Peel off and discard the connective muscle from each scallop. Blot scallops dry with a paper towel.

Heat the oil in a cast-iron or heavy-bottomed frypan over high heat (preferably, use a seasoned pan with a non-stick patina). Once oil is shimmering, pat scallops dry again and season both sides. Place in a hot pan.

Sear scallops on the first side until deep golden brown, about 3 min. Turn over and add 1 tbsp (15 mL) butter to the pan. When the butter melts and foams, spoon it over the scallops. Cook until the second side is also deep golden brown, about 2 min. Remove the pan from heat. Transfer scallops to serving plates or platters.

Return the frypan to the heat. Add the diced apple, sautéing in the residual oil and butter, until lightly caramelized, about 1 min. Working quickly, stir in the apple cider, 2 tbsp (30 mL) water, lemon zest, lemon juice and honey. Cook, stirring often, until the liquids are reduced and thickened and the apple is just tender, about 4 min.

Remove the pan from the heat, stir in the remaining 1 tbsp (15 mL) butter until it is blended into the sauce. Add the chives. Spoon the apple and brown butter pan sauce over top of the scallops to serve.
hits.featuredImageAltText: Large plate with the seared scallops and apple and brown butter sauce with a red fork on the plate.

hits.title: Baingan Bharta

ingredients.ingredient: halved cherry tomatoes, about 454 g (1 lb)
Chalo Naan or Roti, warmed, to serve

steps: Preheat the oven to 475°F (246°C).
Set the eggplant on a baking sheet. Roast until the skin has deepened in colour and the flesh is extremely soft, 45-55 mins. Transfer to a rack and let stand until cool enough to handle, 20 mins.
Slice each eggplant lengthwise down the centre. Using a spoon, scoop the flesh out of the skin. Roughly chop the flesh, then transfer to a bowl, along with any juices. Discard skin.

Heat oil in a large pot over medium heat. Add onion and ½ tsp (2 mL) salt. Cook, stirring often, until the onion is soft and beginning to turn golden, 8 to 10 min. Stir in garlic and ginger. Cook, stirring often, until fragrant, 1-2 mins. Stir in turmeric to combine. Stir in tomatoes, chilis and ¼ tsp (1 mL) of salt. Increase the heat to medium-high and cook, stirring often, until the tomatoes have wrinkled and are very jammy, 5-7 mins. Stir in eggplant and any juices. Cook until warmed through and fully combined, 2-4 mins more. Remove from heat and stir in lemon juice, garam masala, and the remaining ¼ tsp (1 mL) of salt, if needed.
Transfer the baingan bharta to a serving bowl. Garnish with cilantro. Serve with naan or roti.
hits.featuredImageAltText: One big bowl of Baingan Bharta with a wooden spoon in it plus a plate with torn pieces of naan off to the side and some of the garnish as well.
hits.metaTitle: Baingan Bharta | Sobeys Inc.
hits.metaDescription: This Baingan Bharta features roasted eggplant cooked with onion, tomatoes, and spices, finished with lemon juice and cilantro. Serve with warm naan or roti.

hits.title: Crispy Mongolian Beef

ingredients.ingredient: Sterling Silver® Tri-tip or Blade Steak, thinly sliced against the grain
Sauce (can use a prepared Mongolian beef sauce):
Shaoxing cooking wine (substitute Mirin if you can’t find)
corn starch (mix with 2 tsp./10 mL of water to make a slurry)
green onion stalks, white part included, cut into 1” (0.635 cm) pieces

steps: Before slicing the beef, place thawed meat into the freezer for 30 minutes to 1 hour. This will help you to thinly slice the beef (optional).
Remove from the freezer and slice thin, ¼" (.635 cm) strips, against the grain.
Combine the water, cornstarch and baking soda and thoroughly whisk until combined and there are no lumps.

Add the remaining ingredients to the mix and whisk to combine. Place beef strips into a resealable plastic bag and pour the marinade over the strips. Massage the bag to coat all the strips evenly. Marinate for a minimum of 1 hour and no more than 2. Store in the refrigerator
Set aside and make the sauce.

For the sauce: If using jarred sauce: Add the jarred sauce to a pot and heat through, remove from heat once complete. If making your own sauce, add the soy sauce, chicken stock, sweet chili sauce, wine, hoisin, and Sriracha to the pot and bring it to a rapid boil.
Add the brown sugar, salt and pepper to the pot. Turn the heat down to simmer.

Combine the cornstarch and water in a separate small bowl to create a slurry. Add the slurry to the sauce and bring it back to a rapid boil, then simmer until the sauce thickens and coats the back of a spoon. Set aside until needed to add to the beef.
For the vegetables: Cut the red pepper and remove the stem and seeds. Slice into ¼" / (0.635 cm) strips about 1 to 1 ½" / (0.635 x 2.5 cm) in length.
Mince the garlic. Grate the ginger with a microplane (or use jarred ginger). Slice the green onion into 1/4" (0.635 cm) slices
Pour the vegetable oil into a sauce pot and place on medium-high heat.  Add the red peppers, green onions, garlic and ginger and cook for approximately 5 minutes until the peppers begin to soften.
For the Mongolian beef preparation: Remove the beef from the bag and thoroughly dredge in the cornstarch on both sides of the meat.

Heat the oil over high heat in a skillet or wok. Once it heats up, add the slices of beef in small batches, cooking on both sides for approximately 1 minute per side. Remove from the oil and set aside until all the beef is cooked and crispy.
Once all the beef is cooked, remove all but ¼ cup (60 mL) of the oil. Pour the prepared sauce into the heated wok. Heat the sauce for 1 minute, then add the cooked beef and green onions.
Cook until the beef is coated and most of the sauce is clinging to the beef and there is only a small amount of sauce. Place cooked beef onto a platter and serve with steamed rice.
hits.featuredImageAltText: A plate with the crispy Mongolian beef and some white rice, chopsticks on the side, a small bowl of sauce, another bowl of white rice, and a wok full of the beef and colourful vegetables.

hits.title: Peanut Tang Yuan Dumplings

ingredients.ingredient: piece ginger, peeled and sliced into rounds
1 cup (250 mL) plus 2 tbsp (30 mL) glutinous rice flour, plus extra for kneading dough

steps: To prepare the soup: In a medium saucepan, combine water, brown sugar, and ginger. Bring to a full boil over high heat, stirring occasionally to dissolve sugar. Remove from heat, cover and set aside.

To prepare the filling: In a small bowl, mix the brown sugar with the butter until smooth. Stir in the peanut butter until it is fully combined. Stir in the coconut. Freeze until mixture can easily be rolled into balls, approximately 30 mins.
Scoop 1 tsp (5 mL) portions of filling and roll into 12 smooth balls. Arrange on a parchment-lined plate or tray. Freeze until firm, 30 mins.

While filling freezes, prepare the dough: In a large bowl, add flour. Slowly drizzle over the hot kettle-boiled water, stirring with a fork, until mixture is fully combined (dough will be coarse and crumbly). Cover with plastic wrap and let stand for 20 mins.
Boil a large pot of water. Lightly flour the work surface with glutinous rice flour.

Knead the dough in the bowl until it is fully combined, then transfer it to the work surface and continue to knead, adding extra flour if the dough sticks, until it is very smooth and elastic. Roll the dough into an even log, then cut into 12 equal pieces.
Remove the filling from the freezer.

Working with one piece of dough at a time, flatten it into a round circle large enough to contain the filling. Place a portion of the filling in the centre of each round. Gather the sides around the filling to completely enclose it. Pinch the seams all together at the top to fully seal, then roll into a smooth ball. Set finished dumpling on a plate and repeat with the remaining dough and filling.

Boil the dumplings, gently stirring occasionally, until they float to the top of the water, 2-3 minutes. Continue cooking for 1 more minute. Using a slotted spoon, remove the dumplings to a large bowl of cold water.
Rewarm soup over medium heat, then add dumplings. Cook until warmed through, 1-2 mins. Divide the dumplings and soup among the bowls. Serve immediately.
hits.metaDescription: These Peanut Tang Yuan Dumplings are soft and chewy, filled with sweet peanut butter, and served in a ginger-flavoured soup. They are shareable and delicious!

hits.title: Sweet & Smoky Glazed Pork Belly Bites with Asian-Style Slaw

ingredients.ingredient: skin-on or skin-off pork belly, cut into 1-inch cubes
Extra sliced green onions, for garnish (optional)

steps: Preheat oven to 375°F (190°C). If your pork belly has skin, score it deeply but not all the way through, then pat it very dry. Cut the pork belly into roughly 1-inch (2.5 cm) cubes.

In a large bowl, drizzle the pork belly cubes with 1 tbsp of olive oil. Now, sprinkle 2 tbsp of Matheson Food Company Sweeter Seasoning over the cubes. Toss thoroughly, ensuring every piece is coated. This initial layer of Sweeter seasoning will start to build that amazing sweet and savoury foundation.
Spread the seasoned pork belly in a single layer on a foil-lined baking sheet. Bake for 30 minutes.
Asian-Style Slaw: While the pork belly is baking, combine all the slaw ingredients in a large bowl. Toss well and set aside to allow the flavours to meld.

After 30 minutes, remove the pork belly from the oven. At this point, the fat will have rendered, and the cubes will be starting to crisp. Lightly sprinkle the pork belly with an additional 1 tbsp of Matheson Food Company Sweeter Seasoning, tossing gently to coat.

Return the pork belly to the oven and continue baking for another 15-30 minutes, or until the pork belly is deeply golden brown, crispy on the edges, and incredibly tender. Keep an eye on it to prevent burning.

Once the pork belly is cooked and glazed, remove it from the oven. Let cool for a minute or two. Serve the hot, crispy, sweet & smoky pork belly bites immediately alongside your fresh, tangy Asian-Style Slaw. Garnish with toasted sesame seeds and extra green onions if desired. Get ready for applause!

title.value: Sweet & Smoky Glazed Pork Belly Bites with Asian-Style Slaw

steps.value: Preheat oven to 375°F (190°C). If your pork belly has skin, score it deeply but not all the way through, then pat it very dry. Cut the pork belly into roughly 1-inch (2.5 cm) cubes.

In a large bowl, drizzle the pork belly cubes with 1 tbsp of olive oil. Now, sprinkle 2 tbsp of Matheson Food Company Sweeter Seasoning over the cubes. Toss thoroughly, ensuring every piece is coated. This initial layer of Sweeter seasoning will start to build that amazing sweet and savoury foundation.
Spread the seasoned pork belly in a single layer on a foil-lined baking sheet. Bake for 30 minutes.
Asian-Style Slaw: While the pork belly is baking, combine all the slaw ingredients in a large bowl. Toss well and set aside to allow the flavours to meld.

After 30 minutes, remove the pork belly from the oven. At this point, the fat will have rendered, and the cubes will be starting to crisp. Lightly sprinkle the pork belly with an additional 1 tbsp of Matheson Food Company Sweeter Seasoning, tossing gently to coat.

Return the pork belly to the oven and continue baking for another 15-30 minutes, or until the pork belly is deeply golden brown, crispy on the edges, and incredibly tender. Keep an eye on it to prevent burning.

Once the pork belly is cooked and glazed, remove it from the oven. Let cool for a minute or two. Serve the hot, crispy, sweet & smoky pork belly bites immediately alongside your fresh, tangy Asian-Style Slaw. Garnish with toasted sesame seeds and extra green onions if desired. Get ready for applause!

hits.title: 3 ways with Compliments Unsalted Deluxe Mixed Nuts
hits.articleInitialText: Must-try snacks made with Compliments Unsalted Deluxe Mixed Nuts Sure, these nuts are super as a snack on their own, but we love using them in a variety of recipes, too.Here are our faves.
hits.bannerText: 3 ways with compliments unsalted deluxe mixed nuts

heroTiles.description: This crowd-pleaser is perfect for pool parties, movie nights under the stars, BBQs, and beyond. Even better? It’s super easy to make. Simply mix together Compliments Pretzel Sticks, your favourite crisp rice and wheat cereals, and Unsalted Deluxe Mixed Nuts. Make a big batch using equal amounts of each. You can always customize it to your taste, adding more deluxe nuts as desired.

We’ve gone ahead and revamped the recipe for “Good Old Raisins and Peanuts” with gourmet additions that go together like the sun and the beach. Mix together equal amounts of Compliments Unsalted Mixed Nuts, Compliments Raisins or Compliments Dried Cranberries, dried apricots (or mango!) and salted seeds like pumpkin and/or sunflower. For a treat, toss in candy-coated chocolate or Compliments Chocolate Chips. This energy-packed snack will be a hit from road trips to hikes to any other adventure the summer holds.

These are the kind of snack bars your gang will love: sweet and salty, crunchy and chewy, packed with hunger-halting ingredients – and easy to make. In a measuring glass, melt 1/3 cup honey and 3 tbsp peanut butter in the microwave, then stir until smooth. Pour mixture over a large bowl with 1½ cups each Compliments Deluxe Mixed Nuts and Compliments Toasted Puffed Wheat Cereal, 1/3 cup semi-sweet Chocolate Chips, ¼ cup each dried cranberries and pumpkin seeds, and 3 tbsp flax or chia seeds. Gently toss until mixed. Scrape the mixture into an 8-inch baking pan lined with parchment paper and mist with cooking Spray, pressing evenly with the bottom of the measuring cup. Refrigerate until set, about 2 or 3 hours. Cut into bars. TIP: Prefer balls to bars? Roll the mixture into bite-sized balls before refrigerating.

hits.title: Reducing Sodium
hits.articleInitialText:
With most of us consuming about double the amount of salt we should in a day, there are plenty of good reasons – whether you or someone you know is currently managing heart disease or not – to believe that overall, our risks for sodium-intake-related health problems are climbing. So, here are some tips for shaking off your bad sodium habits for good.

Know your limit. The maximum daily recommendation for adults is 2,300 mg of sodium – to help you visualize, this amounts to 1 tsp (5 mL) of table salt. Dietitians suggest falling between 1,500 and 2,300 mg a day. That’s probably a lot less than you think, so it’s worth calculating your daily intake.

Add a squeeze of citrus. Instead of sprinkling on salt, use lemon, lime, grapefruit and orange juice or a grating of fresh zest to give meat, fish and vegetables a flavour lift. Or use your favourite flavoured vinegar — instead of extra salt — to add zip to soups, stews and sauces.

Read labels on pantry staples. To save on sodium, make the better food switch to low salt versions of your favourite foods. Big culprits are items such as canned tomatoes, soups, broths and vegetable juices – now available in low-salt versions that are often just as enjoyable.

Go for fresh garlic and onion. This flavourful pair adds interest to almost any dish. Use them fresh rather than powdered, which may contain extra salt.

Cut back gradually. Salt is an acquired taste, so reducing it slowly and subtly will give your taste buds a chance to adjust. We promise, once you start cutting down, you won’t reach for the shaker as often.

Cook more often. Only 11% of the salt we eat daily comes from meals prepared in our own kitchens, while restaurant meals and processed foods account for close to 80% (the rest comes from natural sources). So, the more food you make yourself, the less salt you’ll consume.

Sprinkle on herbs and spices. Herbs (fresh or dried) and spices add dimension to any dish without the need for salt. We are huge believers that with more flavourful ingredients, few of us will miss the salt.

Seek out its hiding places. Salt is often used in canned goods as a preservative, so be sure to rinse tinned beans and opt for frozen and fresh vegetables when you can. Sodium can lurk in less obvious places too, including desserts and – surprise – some of your favourite flavoured takeout coffee drinks.

Learn the vocabulary. Brined, pickled, smoked, cured and corned all signal higher sodium. And while it may go by another name — kosher, coarse, sea — it should tell you that more sodium has been added.

Shopping for Low Sodium & Sodium-Free Foods

For all of you who are looking to learn about and select products that contain less salt, we created a Low Sodium & Sodium-Free Natural Source Product List to help you find these alternatives more easily. You’ll find all these products in our Natural Source department.

Low Sodium or Sodium-Free labels are based on guidelines determined by Health Canada and information provided by product manufacturers on the Nutrition Facts Table of the product. Health Canada deems a product to be Low Sodium if there are 140 mg of sodium or less per serving. A product is deemed Sodium Free by Health Canada if there are less than 5 mg of sodium per serving.

hits.title: How Food Can Boost Your Energy & Mood
hits.bannerText: How Food Can Boost Your Energy & Mood
hits.initialText:
As the air turns crisp and the days get shorter, schedules get busier and life can sometimes feel like a juggling act. On busy days, eating properly is essential to your health and well being.

“A balanced diet is key to positively influencing energy levels and mood,” says registered dietitian Kristy Hogger.

Imagine your body as a luxury car and the food you eat as your fuel. Just as the type of fuel affects the performance of a car, the foods you eat can affect your mood, energy levels and even how well you function at work or school.

“The way we feel is certainly influenced by what we eat,” says Hogger. “Our food choices can help us feel better or worse.”

If you’re feeling sluggish, try adding more energy-boosting foods to your diet. Hogger offers these tasty options to get you started.

Eggs

Eggs are an excellent source of protein and a source of iron, folate and vitamin E (6 g of  protein, 0.7 mg iron, 36 mcg of folate, 1.2 mg of vitamin E per 50 g serving).

“The protein in eggs contains all nine essential amino acids necessary for building and repairing muscle tissue,” says Hogger.

Get cracking with Devilled Eggs with Chives. Chives lend subtle onion flavour and crunch to the familiar staple.

“One serving provides 6 g of protein, as well as the other nutritional benefits of eggs,” says Hogger.

Chorizo & Sweet Potato Frittata spices up eggs with cured hot sausage, cheddar cheese and cubed sweet potato.

“A frittata is great for breakfast or brunch,” says Hogger. “In addition to the eggs providing protein, the sweet potato is an excellent source of vitamin A.”

For snacks, slice any leftover frittata into bite-sized cubes and place in a portable container, skewering each piece onto a toothpick. Tip: Use omega-3 eggs, which have some different nutritional benefits.

Greens

Greens don’t just taste great — they are part of your healthy lifestyle. Eating Well with Canada’s Food Guide recommends including at least one serving of dark green vegetables each day.  Also some research suggests there’s a link between depression and low levels of folate, a B vitamin also known as folic acid. Foods like spinach are an excellent source folate (125 mcg per 65 g serving).

Getting your greens can be easy. Start by adding more spinach, broccoli and romaine lettuce to your diet. Add texture to sandwiches with a layer of crisp romaine, or boost your everyday salad by tossing in some tender spinach.

Here are some tasty recipes featuring greens:

  • Chopped Broccolini & Spinach Salad
  • Orange Teriyaki Pork Chops with Bok Choy
  • Zucchini & Spinach Pesto
  • Creamy Avocado Pasta with Baby Kale & Salmon
  • Green Beans with Caramelized Onions

Pumpkin Seeds

Whether tossed into trail mix or eaten on their own, pumpkin seeds can give your body a boost.

"Pumpkin seeds are rich in magnesium, which is an important mineral for bone health and helps keep muscles and nerves healthy," says Hogger.

One-quarter cup of roasted pumpkin seeds provides 9 g of protein and 4 g of omega-3 polyunsaturated fats. This amount also provides one serving of meat and alternatives from Canada’s Food Guide.

Craving a sweet treat? Get your fix from a slice of Zucchini Loaf with Walnuts & Pumpkin Seeds.

“The nuts and seeds offer heart-healthy fats, including monounsaturated and omega-3 fatty acids,” says Hogger. “And the whole wheat flour contributes fibre.”

Or make a batch of No Cook Fruit & Oat Bars . Studded with pumpkin seeds, it’s a homemade grab-and-go snack that will last all week.

“These bars are a source of omega-3 fatty acids from the chia seeds and a good source of magnesium from the pumpkin seeds,” says Hogger.

Nuts

Nuts are packed with flavour and great for munching by the handful or tossing into a variety of dishes. But here’s another big bonus: nuts such as hazelnuts, almonds and walnuts may also enhance mood.

“One study found that people who consumed ¼ cup (60 mL) of mixed nuts per day had higher levels of serotonin, a brain chemical that helps regulate mood, compared to those who avoided nuts,” says Hogger.

Nuts also make a great portable snack — perfect for stashing in your bag for grazing on the go. And we love the crunchy texture they add to entrées and desserts. Enjoy walnuts in our Spiced Apple Salad with Granola or bake our easy Pumpkin, Cranberry & Pecan Loaf.

The sweet, buttery taste of hazelnuts can perk up salads and mains, while almonds add a satisfying crunch to many dishes. Try almonds in our recipes for Cheese & Broccoli Topped Chicken and Apple-Raspberry Crisp, or try hazelnuts in our Harvest Vegetable Crumble.

Dark Chocolate

Dark chocolate may have a positive effect on mood, as suggested by some studies. And while more research is required, it contains phytochemicals, like flavonoids. More flavonoids means darker chocolate and potentially greater health benefits.

“A small amount eaten regularly can help reduce the risk of heart attack, lower blood pressure, improve good cholesterol and increase blood flow,” says Hogger.

Be mindful of serving sizes and the type of chocolate you buy. “Choose high-quality dark chocolate that’s at least 70% cocoa, which has more flavonoids than milk chocolate,” says Hogger. “And limit portion size to avoid overindulging in sugar and calories.” A serving of 30 g (1 oz) is enough to offer antioxidant benefits.

Stash Chocolate & Cherry Granola Bars in your bag in case hunger strikes on the road.

“Delicious pecans, almonds and dark chocolate have flavonoid antioxidants, monounsaturated fats and fibre,” says Hogger.

Or throw dark chocolate chunks into the delicious Popcorn, Fruit & Nut Trail Mix.

“The nuts, seeds and popcorn provide carbohydrate, protein and fibre to give you energy,” says Hogger. “And the added benefit of antioxidants from dark chocolate makes this a winning recipe!”

Fish

Fresh, flaky and delicate fish is a tasty and affordable solution, whether for a weeknight or special occasion. “We are also starting to understand that omega-3 fatty acids, which are found in some kinds of fish, may help improve mood and relieve symptoms of depression,” says Hogger.  Boost your intake by adding salmon, mackerel and sardines to your diet.

Whether you’re pan-frying, roasting or baking fish, it’s a versatile protein that cooks quickly. Learn more about types of fish here, and get inspired by these recipes:

  • Pan-Fried Salmon with Lentil-Carrot Salad
  • Tilapia with Creamy Dill Sauce
  • Prosciutto-Wrapped Haddock with Spring Pasta
  • Po’ Boy-Style Cod Sandwich
  • Roasted Halibut with Capers, Olives & Tomatoes
  • Pan-Fried Salmon with Lentil-Carrot Salad
  • Tilapia with Creamy Dill Sauce
  • Prosciutto-Wrapped Haddock with Spring Pasta
  • Po’ Boy-Style Cod Sandwich
  • Roasted Halibut with Capers, Olives & Tomatoes

hits.title: Five fast and easy ways to dress up a store-bought pie
hits.articleInitialText:
Want to dress up your favourite Thanksgiving pie with quick and easy toppings that are sure to please? We’ve got five fabulous hacks that take mere minutes to prepare and deliver on both taste and wow factor. Who says you can’t have your pie and eat it, too?

Putting together an entire Thanksgiving dinner can seem daunting, but we’ve got time and turkey-saving tips and tricks up our sleeves that you can use to pull it off. And to vault you to superstar-cook status, we’ve got five dessert hacks, so you can focus on everything else.

Our Compliments frozen and bakery-ready pies in traditional pumpkin and apple and also pecan are fabulous on their own, but for those who want those oohs and aahs around the table, these hacks are tailor-made for you!
hits.bannerText: Five fast and easy ways to dress up a store-bought pie

heroTiles.description:
Whip up a quick and easy meringue, then load it up atop a Compliments Pumpkin Pie. The crowning glory is the torched meringue with its golden peaks and swirls for both a show stopping dessert and that roasted-marshmallow flavour that can’t be beat. Here’s how:

In a bowl, using an electric mixer on medium speed, beat together 10 tbsp (150 mL) room temperature pasteurized egg white product and ¼ tsp (1 mL) cream of tartar until foamy, 1 to 2 min. Beat in 10 tbsp (150 mL) granulated sugar, 1 tbsp (15 mL) at a time, until meringue is glossy and stiff peaks form, 2 to 3 min. Pile meringue in centre of Compliments Pumpkin Pie; with back of spoon, create peaks and swirls. Toast peaks of meringue with a crème brûlée torch, or broil pie in centre of oven, rotating every 30 sec., until peaks are golden-brown, 2 to 3 min. Garnish with pecans, if desired.

Tip: Make sure the bowl and beaters are clean, dry, and free of any oil, which may prevent egg whites from whipping properly.

heroTiles.herotitle: 2. Salted Dark Chocolate and Pretzel Pecan Pie
heroTiles.description:
Take a tasty Compliments Pecan Pie to a whole new dimension by topping with a thin, smooth layer of homemade dark chocolate ganache. We up the ante by garnishing with mini pretzels, toasted pecans, and sea salt for a savoury textural crunch to offset the sweet filling. In about 10 min., you’ll go from good to “oh, my pie!” Here’s how:

Finely chop a 100 g (3½ oz) pkg of dark chocolate. In a microwaveable bowl, microwave chopped chocolate with 1½ tbsp (20 mL) 35% cream, stirring halfway, until smooth, 30 to 45 sec. Pour melted chocolate over top Compliments Pecan Pie and spread evenly to the edge. Arrange ⅓ cup (75 mL) each mini pretzels and lightly roasted pecan halves over chocolate. Sprinkle with ¼ tsp (1 mL) flaked sea salt.

heroTiles.herotitle: 3. Apple Pie with Warm Spiced Cranberry Sauce
heroTiles.description:
Give our deconstructed take on a cranberry-apple pie a whirl with this easy hack. For this, you’ll take a warm homemade cranberry sauce and serve it over a slice of Compliments Apple Pie for a spiced, sweet, and tangy combination that’s sure to please. Here’s how:

In a small saucepan over medium heat, combine 1½ cups (375 mL) frozen or fresh cranberries with ½ cup granulated sugar, ¼ tsp (1 mL) cinnamon and pinch allspice. Cook, stirring occasionally, until cranberries burst, 1 to 2 min. Reduce heat to medium-low. Simmer, stirring occasionally, until sauce starts to thicken, 7 to 10 min. Set aside to cool slightly. Serve slices of Compliments Apple Pie topped with a spoonful of warm cranberry sauce.

Sometimes, all it takes is one ingredient to turn your pie from simple to simply exquisite. Try this sugar-topped, brûléed technique on your Compliments Pumpkin pie and top with ripe fall fruit like figs, raspberries, and blackberries. You’ll be the belle of the ball. You’ll need a hand torch for this one, which can come in handy when you’re making other treats like any one of these ooey-gooey s'mores. Here’s how to get that brûléed effect:

Using the back of a spoon, gently press down on edges of Compliments Pumpkin Pie to create a smooth, flat surface. Sprinkle 6 to 8 tbsp. granulated sugar evenly over pie to the edges. Caramelize sugar with a crème brûlée torch until melted and golden. Garnish with fall fruit (such as quartered figs, blackberries, raspberries), if desired. Serve immediately.

Tip: Using more sugar will create a thicker sugar “crust” which will give a nice shatter effect when broken.

heroTiles.herotitle: 5. Apple Crumble Pie and Peanut Butter-Yogurt Breakfast Parfait
heroTiles.description:
It’s hard to believe there might be pie left over from your Thanksgiving feast. But just in case, we’ve got this delicious breakfast parfait at the ready using leftover Compliments Apple Crumble Pie layered with a peanut butter-vanilla yogurt for an easy, satisfying way to start your day. The pie’s crumble layer and crust add a tasty, granola-like crunch to the parfait.

Tip: These are perfectly portable too (in jars), in case you’re on dessert duty and are invited to a brunch or informal get-together. Here’s how to make it:

Stir 2 cups Greek yogurt with 1 tsp vanilla, and ½ cup natural peanut butter (creamy or crunchy) in a medium bowl until smooth. Alternate layers of chopped Compliments Apple Crumble pie and peanut butter-yogurt in glasses or small jars, ending with yogurt layer. Sprinkle with peanuts, if desired.

hits.title: Summer bucket list snacks
hits.articleInitialText: Fuel your favourite summer activities with the perfect snacks. Our plan for the best-ever summer? Park picnics, lounging poolside, road trips, camping retreats, repeat. The only thing missing from our summer bucket list are the snacks suited to each activity. Here’s our shopping list.

heroTiles.description:
Long days on the open road call for a mix of salty and sweet: Foods that go well with a good mood, great chats, and hearty laughs; snacks to stave off hunger when the next stop is a few hours away; and don’t forget thirst-quenching sips between singalongs.

Shopping List:

  • Compliments Maple & Aged White Cheddar Popcorn
  • Compliments Milk Chocolate Covered Cashews
  • Compliments Sparkling Water …in all flavours!

Bright sun and blue skies with nary a cloud in sight? This calls for a day spent by the pool. Packing for this one is easy: a cooler full of all the iced treats we can carry! Think refreshing ice pops in your favourite juicy flavours, and silky-smooth ice cream sandwiched between chewy chocolate cookie layers. We’ll have it all!

Shopping List:

  • Compliments Ice Cream Sandwiches
  • Compliments Assorted Twin Ice Pops

Whether you’re going camping for a night or a week, you need to pack light and consider what can be cooked over an open flame. We like to keep it classic with smoky hot dogs, which are an eternal family favourite. And, of course, a camping trip wouldn’t be complete without rich, gooey, chocolatey s’mores to accompany campfire ghost stories.

Shopping List:

  • Compliments S’Mores Kits
  • Compliments Wieners
  • Compliments Hot Dog Buns
  • Compliments Tomato Ketchup
  • Compliments Prepared Mustard

Break out that gingham blanket and wicker basket because park picnics are a summer must! Pack hearty snacks to graze on between games of Frisbee and catch (we like the idea of soft, chewy dippers in rich creamy dips), refreshments to keep your thirst quenched (sparkling always does the trick), and crunchy, salty treats to munch on as you chat (when it comes to picnic chips, always go for the biggest bag possible). All that’s left to do? Laugh, people-watch, play, and let the day turn to night.

Shopping List:

  • Compliments Value Size Chips
  • Compliments Bacon Ranch Dip
  • Compliments Mexican Street-Style Corn Dip
  • Compliments Naan Dippers
  • Compliments Sparkling Water

Think refreshing ice pops in your favourite juicy flavours, and silky-smooth ice cream sandwiched between chewy chocolate cookie layers. We’ll have it all!

Shopping List:

  • Compliments Ice Cream Sandwiches
  • Compliments Assorted Twin Ice Pops

Whether you’re going camping for a night or a week, you need to pack light and consider what can be cooked over an open flame. We like to keep it classic with smoky hot dogs, which are an eternal family favourite. And, of course, a camping trip wouldn’t be complete without rich, gooey, chocolatey s’mores to accompany campfire ghost stories.

Shopping List:

  • Compliments S’Mores Kits
  • Compliments Wieners
  • Compliments Hot Dog Buns
  • Compliments Tomato Ketchup
  • Compliments Prepared Mustard

Break out that gingham blanket and wicker basket because park picnics are a summer must! Pack hearty snacks to graze on between games of Frisbee and catch (we like the idea of soft, chewy dippers in rich creamy dips), refreshments to keep your thirst quenched (sparkling always does the trick), and crunchy, salty treats to munch on as you chat (when it comes to picnic chips, always go for the biggest bag possible). All that’s left to do? Laugh, people-watch, play, and let the day turn to night.

Shopping List:

hits.title: Leftovers Challenge: 8 Ways to Use Leftover Cabbage
hits.bannerText: Leftovers Challenge: 8 Ways to Use Leftover Cabbage
hits.initialText:
Often purchased with great intentions, a head of cabbage is one of those ingredients that is hard to use up in just one recipe. Instead of leaving the leftovers to wilt in your fridge, give one of these fast and easy meal ideas a try.

How to shred cabbage: Cut a head of cabbage into quarters, remove and discard the cores and use a sharp knife to slice each piece into shreds. Slicing horizontally will give you shorter ribbons, while slicing vertically yields longer ones.

1. Turn it into a slaw: This classic crunchy salad is super easy to prepare and the ideal side dish for meat, fish or tofu. Toss shredded cabbage into a large bowl with a tangy oil-and-vinegar blend or any mayonnaise-based dressing. Other raw vegetables, such as carrot, celery or radish, are tasty candidates to shred and stir in, too. Bonus: It’s easy to personalize your slaw with fresh herbs, nuts or even chopped apples for extra flavour and texture.

Try it: Asian-Style Grilled Chicken Slaw

2. Pickle it: Making a quick fridge-friendly pickle prolongs cabbage’s life without the intricacies of shelf-stable canning. Use it as a sandwich or taco topping, or as a fresh garnish for seared fish or chicken. Pickled cabbage also makes a surprisingly tasty addition to a cheese platter—the acidity nicely complements both rich and sharp cheeses.

Try it: Quick Pickled Slaw

3. Add it to soups: Stir chopped or shredded cabbage into a variety of soups to add bulk and a hearty flavour. For an eastern European–style soup, start with chicken broth and toss in cabbage, chopped cooked potatoes, diced kielbasa sausage and chopped dill; serve it with a dollop of sour cream. Or make an Asian-inspired cabbage soup with a soy- or mushroom-based broth, noodles, cabbage, carrots and thinly sliced green onions.

Try it: Make Fall Minestrone with Turkey & Squash, using shredded cabbage in place of the broccoli.

4. Stir it into stir-fries: Chopped cabbage adds a pleasing crunch to everyday stir-fries. Add it to the pan near the end of cooking and stir-fry until tender-crisp. Mix in your favourite sauce and serve over steamed white rice. Top your dish with toasted sesame seeds, a little chopped cilantro and a lime wedge. You can also use shredded cabbage when making homemade fried rice.

Try it: Make our Teriyaki Stir-Fry and add shredded cabbage in with the other vegetables.

5. Swap it for lettuce: Finely shredded cabbage makes a delicious substitute for iceberg lettuce. Use it in sandwiches, wraps, tacos or salads. You can also try it as a pizza topper.

Try it: Honey Garlic Grilled Chicken Sandwich with Creamy Coleslaw

6. Load it onto a baked potato: For an easy, vegetable-rich meal that tastes like comfort food, top baked sweet potatoes with drained and rinsed kidney beans, a pile of chopped or shredded cabbage, a drizzle of olive oil and a sprinkling of cheese, bacon or your favourite nuts.

Discover more ways to top your baked potatoes.

7. Add texture to meat-based dishes: Sauté shredded cabbage with garlic and dried parsley until the mixture softens. Let it cool slightly, and then add it to meatballs, meatloaf or a casserole. Sautéed cabbage is tasty in lasagna, too. Simply stir it into the tomato sauce and sprinkle in dried basil or oregano for flavour. Using cabbage is an easy way to bulk up your veggie intake and further stretch your meat budget.

Try it: Add shredded cabbage to our Basic Meatloaf with Creamy Tomato Sauce.

8. Load it up with delicious fillings: The cabbage’s inner leaves make a sturdy substitute for burger buns and tortilla wraps. You can also try them as cups for holding meats, cheeses and other favourite sandwich stuff.

Try it: Serve our Ultimate Burger on cabbage leaves instead of Kaiser rolls.

hits.title: How to Make Freezer Jam
hits.articleInitialText:
It’s as simple as 1, 2, 3 – mash, mix and freeze! Freezer jam comes together in a snap and can be tucked into the freezer for those long winter months when you’d give anything for a fresh peach.

All you need is fruit, sugar and pectin designed for freezer jam. If you’ve never canned or made jam, this is a great way to build your DIY confidence, since most of the trickier parts of traditional canning can be skipped.

Unlike its cooked cousin, freezer jam requires zero cooking – a bonus in the summer! Once you’ve combined the mashed fruit, sugar and pectin, it’s important to let the sugar and pectin dissolve. Divide your finished jam into containers and store in the freezer – hence the name, freezer jam.

  • Peaches, raspberries and strawberries all make wonderful freezer jam. A good rule of thumb to remember: if you can mash the fruit, it can be freezer jam!
  • Because you don’t cook freezer jam, make sure that the fruit you’re using is nice and ripe.
  • Skipping the cooking process allows you to add even more flavour with fresh herbs. Herbs that you would traditionally use in desserts – basil, mint and lavender – make next-level freezer jam.
  • Since you’re storing the jam in the freezer, you can skip the sterilization and boiling. Simply wash jars and lids with warm, soapy water and rinse and dry well.
  • Don’t be surprised: the consistency of no-cook freezer jam is thinner than traditional jam.
  • Freezer jam can be stored in the freezer for up to a year. Once you take it out, it will keep in the fridge for a few weeks.

hits.title: Sweet Ways with Fresh Corn on the Cob
hits.articleInitialText:
Fresh corn is one of summer’s most loved vegetables. Sweet, crisp and endlessly versatile, it’s the side dish to some of your favourite summer meals. And we have all the tips you need to enjoy it, from husking to cooking.

Buy the best

There are a few telltale signs of freshness to look for when buying corn.

  • The silk sticking out of a cob should be slightly damp and brown. Black and dry silk indicates an older cob.
  • Give the cob a gentle squeeze. If the kernels are plump and juicy, the cob is a winner.
  • Don’t husk the corn in store. It’s considered a social faux pas, as some believe exposing the kernels promotes the loss of the corn’s natural sweetness.

Husk smartly

Husking corn was once a difficult process that was necessary to get at the sweet kernels. Not anymore! Simply husk and then rub the cob with a tea towel to remove the remaining silky fibres. Watch how it’s done in our video.

Free the kernels

Behold a culinary trick so cool it can be done in front of an audience! To keep the corn stable and the kernels from flying when cutting them from a cob, wedge the wider end of the cob into the middle of a bundt pan. Firmly grasp the narrow end of the cob and use a paring knife to slice downwards. The best part — the kernels fall neatly into the bundt pan, which makes them easy to scoop up. This trick is great for any recipe that calls for fresh corn and for those who aren’t fans of eating the corn straight off the cob.

Get cooking

Now that the corn is prepped, it’s time to get cooking! Here are some basic preparation methods.

Grilled When it comes to cooking corn on the barbecue, it’s all a matter of taste. Each of these methods creates a different flavour and texture.

  • In the husk – Soak unhusked corn cobs in water for about an hour before placing them on the barbecue. (The wet husk will steam the kernels and protect them from charring.) Grill for 15 to 20 minutes on medium heat for perfectly steamed kernels that are plump and sweet.
  • Wrapped in foil – Remove the husks and place each cob on a piece of aluminum foil. Top with flavoured butter (and any other add-ons you like, such as herbs, bacon bits or sliced green onions), then wrap them up tightly and pop them on the grill for 20 to 30 minutes on medium heat. This results in great flavour infused into every sweet, juicy bite.
  • Right on the grill – For smokey flavour, grill husked corn directly on the grill for about 10 minutes, turning frequently The kernels will caramelize and get slightly crispy but should not be completely charred.

Roasted Don’t have a grill? No problem. Roast corn in the oven. Much like grilling, husked corn can be roasted in or out of foil. Roast foil-wrapped corn for 25 minutes at 450°F. Unwrapped corn can be roasted for 45 minutes at 400°F.

Boiled Bring a large pot of salted water to a boil and gently place husked corn in the water. Bring to a simmer and cook for five minutes. Remove cooked corn from the water and serve.

Recipe Inspiration

Featuring sides, toppers and mains, our collection of recipes will have you enjoying corn all summer long.

Roasted Corn Relish: Husked corn, sweet bell peppers, jalapeños, green onions and lime are grilled to perfection and tossed with cilantro paste, lime juice and salt.

Bacon-Wrapped Barbecued Corn: There are plenty of summer foods that benefit from being wrapped in bacon. Corn is no exception.

Creamy Curried Corn Relish: Rediscover your love for creamed corn with this fresh, curry-spiked relish. It makes a great burger topper or side for grilled chicken.

Layered Corn, Black Bean & Rice Salad: Fans of layered taco dip will flock to this salad. Ready in 25 minutes, it’s a pretty summer salad than makes an impressive potluck contribution.

Shrimp Boil with Sausage, Potatoes & Corn: If there’s one meal with the power to transport taste buds to the East Coast, this is it — casual, communal and guaranteed to put people at ease.

Grilled Herb Butters: Corn on the cob purists swear by boiled corn slathered in a healthy dose of butter. Break from tradition and whip up one of these flavoured butters.

  • Corn on the Cob with Garlic Herb Butter
  • Corn on the Cob with Maple Ginger Butter
  • Corn on the Cob with Blue Cheese Butter

hits.title: What’s in Season? Your Guide to Canadian Produce in the Atlantic Provinces
hits.articleInitialText:
When you buy local fruits and veggies, you’ll enjoy some of the best flavours the season has to offer. When possible, Sobeys carries local produce – any produce grown within your province is considered to be local. In-season produce is picked at the height of its freshness and is often more abundant, so you may see a drop in prices that will help you stretch your budget further (especially if you freeze and preserve to save foods for the rest of the year). Another plus? Supporting Canadian growers feels pretty good too!

This handy chart will help you predict when your favourite homegrown items will reach their peak. Use it to plan your menus and grocery lists.

Note: The following seasonal produce guide is based on an average taken from growers all across the Atlantic provinces. Adjust dates earlier or later depending on the climate and conditions in your particular area. Scroll down for links to local seasonal produce guides for your region.

Click to download a copy of this guide
hits.bannerText: What’s in Season? Your Guide to Canadian Produce in the Atlantic Provinces

heroTiles.description:
The Six Seasons

Spring: In the Atlantic provinces, we see the first fresh produce of the year in late April or early May – like tart rhubarb and fiddleheads.

Early Summer: Fresh produce becomes more abundant from May to June. The first early berries make an appearance, with strawberries dominating the fruit stands, and a wide variety of leafy greens is available. This is also the peak time for sweet summer peas.

Summer: Sunny July and August are the prime months in the Atlantic provinces for fresh produce. Fruits such as cantaloupe, blueberries and strawberries ripen to perfection. Grocery aisles across the provinces are piled high with colourful, ripe field-grown cucumbers and peppers.

Early Fall: September, with its warm days and cooler nights, is a great month for fruits such as apples and pears. Hearty squashes and pumpkins are also available in abundance now. This is definitely pie-making season!

Fall: This is your last chance to get many of the summer-peaking vegetables, such as tomatoes, celery and zucchini, in season. Root vegetables like carrots and beets sweeten up with a touch of frost, and fresh cranberries appear in time for Thanksgiving.

Winter: The colder months are the best time to take advantage of fruits and vegetables that store well, such as apples, cabbage, carrots and potatoes – all ingredients that shine in soups and stews.

hits.title: Global Grill
hits.initialText: Let’s take your grilling game global! From the bold spices of Argentina to the smoky flavours of Portugal, these dishes bring influences from around the world straight to your backyard. Whether you’re hosting a lively cookout or enjoying a casual weekend BBQ, these global grill recipes are sure to impress.

recipeList.description: Fire up the grill for bold, smoky Tandoori Chicken! Marinated in yogurt, garlic, ginger, and a mix of spices, this dish brings classic Indian flavours straight to your backyard. Serve with naan, cucumber raita or a simple salad for a delicious meal.
recipeList.title: Tandoori Chicken

recipeList.description: Spice up your grill with Portuguese-Inspired Piri Piri Hot Honey BBQ Chicken Kabobs. These tender, flame-grilled skewers bring the perfect balance of heat and sweetness, making them an easy crowd favourite at your next summer cookout.
recipeList.title: Portuguese-Inspired Piri Piri Hot Honey BBQ Chicken Kabobs

recipeList.description: Transport your taste buds to South Africa with this Braai platter! Featuring a mouthwatering selection of meats, including sausages, lamb chops, tri-tip steak, and more, this platter is made for sharing at your next BBQ.
recipeList.title: South African-Inspired Braai Platter

recipeList.description: Looking to bring a unique twist to your regular fish recipes? Bring the flavours of the Philippines with this trout! Marinated in a blend of chili powder and cumin, then cooked directly on the grill, you can expect a standout dish with tangy, smoky and umami flavours.
recipeList.title: Filipino-Inspired Grilled Whole Trout with Tomato Pepper Onion Relish

recipeList.description: Experience the bold flavours of Argentinian cuisine right in your backyard. The perfectly grilled tri tip steak is tender and juicy, while the Salsa Criolla, made with fresh bell peppers, red onions, herbs and vinegar, adds a tanginess that complements the rich and smoky meat. This dish is inspired by a true celebration of Argentine grilling tradition!
recipeList.title: Argentinian-Style Tri Tip Steak with Salsa Criolla

hits.title: 7 ways with hot dogs
hits.articleInitialText: Take this BBQ staple to the next level this summer. Beyond classic ketchup and mustard, there are a million ways to dress up your ’dog. Here are seven ways to serve up a little excitement from the grill this summer.

heroTiles.description: The Nacho Nacho ‘Dog offers the best of both worlds. Compliments Brioche Bun + Compliments Game Day All Beef Wiener + Compliments Guacamole dip + Tex-Mex shredded cheese + sliced jalapeños + Compliments Restaurant-Style Tortilla Chips = Two game-day go-to's in one delicious ’dog!

Bring a little bit of the Windy City to Canada with the Chicago ‘dog. All you have to do is combine Compliments Hot Dog Bun, toasted and brushed with melted butter + Compliments Game Day All Beef Wiener + Compliments Dill Pickle spear + Compliments Yellow Mustard + tomato wedges + chopped white onion + Compliments Pickled Peppers = A taste of a Chicagoan classic.

What’s better than grilled corn in the summer? Adding grilled corn to your hot dog, with a Mexican elote-style spin! Compliments Sausage Bun + Compliments Jumbo Wiener + grilled corn + crumbled Compliments Feta Cheese + Compliments Mayonnaise + diced red finger chili + chopped cilantro = the flavours of Mexico in a classic Canadian staple.

Kimchi – a Korean staple of fermented cabbage and seasonings – adds all the spice and tang your hot dog needs this summer. Compliments Hot Dog Bun + Compliments Jumbo Wiener + pan-charred and chopped kimchi + shredded white cabbage + thinly sliced red onion + shredded Compliments Old Cheddar Cheese + kimchi juice mixed with Compliments Mayonnaise drizzle + feather-thin sliced green onions = a hot hot dog with extra zip!

Craving sweet and spicy? Look no further than the Hot Honey Mustard Cheese hot dog. Compliments Sausage Bun + Compliments Jumbo Wiener + grated Compliments White Cheddar Cheese + Compliments Whole Grain Dijon Mustard + Compliments Honey + hot pepper flakes + BBQ until cheese melts = Sweet-spicy-cheesy satisfaction, served.

A staple among wing connoisseurs, Buffalo sauce just expanded its horizons and is now on your favourite summertime meal. Compliments Brioche Bun + Compliments Chicken Wiener + chopped celery + Compliments Blue Cheese Dressing + crumbled blue cheese + Compliments Buffalo Wing Sauce = A hotdog wing-lovers will go wild for.

Add a little seaside spin to your hot dogs this summer by making a surf’n dog. Compliments Brioche Bun + Compliments Game Day All Beef Wiener + Compliments Naturally Simple Pacific White Shrimp + Compliments Taco Seasoning + sliced mango and avocado + Compliments Sour Cream mixed with chopped jalapeño = Surf ’n’ turf, reimagined.

Made with fresh, seasonal ingredients, each pastry is a delicious twist on classic Canadian flavours. Are you ready to take your summer snacking to the next level?

A perfect way to enjoy the best of Canada’s in-season fruit, this fried pastry is topped with creamy vanilla filling, crisp apple slices, and ripe raspberries. It’s a fresh, light treat, made for warm days under the sun.

This sweet fried treat is everything you love about cheesecake— creamy, fruity, and indulgent—tucked onto a warm, golden pastry. Topped with a swirl of sweetened cream cheese, crumbled graham crackers and a mix of juicy berries, it’s tangy, rich, and perfect for sharing (or not!)

heroTilesArticle.description:
This is a sweet fried spin on one of Canada’s most iconic desserts! Start with a delicious golden pastry base and add a layer of creamy homemade custard, buttery coconut crumble topping, and a drizzle of rich dark chocolate to finish. It’s everything you love about a classic Nanaimo bar— now warm, crispy, and even more irresistible.

View Recipe

heroTilesArticle.herotitle: Nutty Maple Candied Bacon Fried Pastry
heroTilesArticle.description:
This sweet-and-salty combo hits all the right notes! Crispy maple-glazed bacon is paired with smooth peanut butter on a golden fried pastry, then topped with a handful of crunchy peanuts. It’s rich, satisfying, and full of bold Canadian flavour.
